abstract.p: Richard LaGravenese letter on May 29 article holds David Auburn erred in taking his joking comment on playwrighting seriously

block.p: In a May 29 Arts pages article, the playwright David Auburn recounted a fiercely negative reaction to a comment I jokingly made in a television interview regarding playwrighting. I said I looked forward to writing a play because I could just have people talk and not worry about plot.

Although I'm just a screenwriter, I'm not so simple-minded as to think that playwrighting has nothing to do with narrative. I was a college theater major, and I've been going to the theater for more than 25 years.

In a May 29 Arts pages article, the playwright David Auburn recounted a fiercely negative reaction to a comment I jokingly made in a television interview regarding playwrighting. I said I looked forward to writing a play because I could just have people talk and not worry about plot.

Although I'm just a screenwriter, I'm not so simple-minded as to think that playwrighting has nothing to do with narrative. I was a college theater major, and I've been going to the theater for more than 25 years.

In theater, a writer rules. Film isn't considered a writer's medium. Screenwriters have little control over how a script is produced. My comment referred to a playwright's freedom to write a play in which people just talk if the writer so desires. Not all playwrights write with a strong narrative. Surely Samuel Beckett's ''Happy Days'' and ''Endgame'' are not driven by story.
It's just plain silly that the gifted Mr. Auburn took the comment literally.
